The Metropolitan Museum of Art is working toward revamping its collection with modern and contemporary art. In the next several years, the museum will introduce more than 2,500 new works by artists in its collection, including new works by artists from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan, and China. The overhaul will involve the establishment of new institutional spaces, construction of new exhibition spaces, and the collection receiving a major facelift.“For more than a decade, the Met has been working toward rethinking our collections and redesigning our exhibitions to reflect the contemporary art movement and its richness of practice,” said Norman Guggenheim Museum director Krista Cooper. “The new institutional architecture will introduce new opportunities for broadening audience and engaging with art and this work is just the beginning: we look forward to working with the public to shape the next edition of the Met.”The redesign will address the Met’s longstanding ambition to present the largest exhibition of contemporary art in the United States.
